stem:
Based on the provided information, prioritize the following nursing interventions for Mr. Johnson. Drag the interventions into the correct order of priority, from highest to lowest.

[drag_drop:1] Administer prescribed mannitol 25g IV STAT.
[drag_drop:2] Elevate the head of the bed to 30 degrees.
[drag_drop:3] Monitor neurological status and vital signs every 15 minutes.
[drag_drop:4] Implement seizure precautions.
[drag_drop:5] Obtain an order for a STAT CT scan of the head.

itemContext.sbar:
S: Robert Johnson, 68-year-old male, admitted at 08:00 today with new onset right-sided weakness and slurred speech. Last known well was at 06:00 this morning.
B: History of hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and atrial fibrillation. Prescribed warfarin, lisinopril, and atorvastatin.
A: At 14:30, GCS is 10 (E2, V3, M5). Pupils equal, reactive but sluggish. Right-sided weakness worsening. BP 180/100 mmHg, HR 92 bpm, RR 24, SpO2 94% on 2L NC, Temp 37.2°C. New onset headache reported. Concerned about possible hemorrhagic stroke and increased ICP.
R: Requesting STAT CT scan of the head to rule out hemorrhage. Guidance needed on BP management and neurological monitoring. Warfarin held on admission. INR result pending.

tabs.content: Na: 140 mEq/L, K: 4.2 mEq/L, Cl: 100 mEq/L, HCO3: 24 mEq/L, BUN: 18 mg/dL, Creatinine: 1.0 mg/dL, Glucose: 110 mg/dL, INR: Pending, PT: Pending, PTT: Pending, Platelets: 250,000/mcL, WBC: 8,000/mcL

tabs.content: 14:30: BP: 180/100 mmHg, HR: 92 bpm, RR: 24, SpO2: 94% on 2L NC, Temp: 37.2°C, GCS: 10 (E2, V3, M5)

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Lisinopril 20 mg PO daily (held), Atorvastatin 40 mg PO daily (held), Warfarin 5 mg PO daily (held), Acetaminophen 650 mg PO PRN for headache (Not administered), Normal Saline 0.9% IV at 50 mL/hr

rationale.correct: Obtaining a STAT CT scan is the highest priority to determine the type of stroke (ischemic or hemorrhagic) and rule out other causes of increased ICP, which will guide further treatment. Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used to reduce ICP. It should be administered promptly to decrease cerebral edema. Neurological status and vital signs must be closely monitored to detect changes in condition and effectiveness of interventions. Elevating the head of the bed promotes venous drainage and reduces ICP. Seizure precautions are important to implement due to the risk of seizures associated with increased ICP and stroke.
rationale.incorrect: Incorrect prioritization may lead to delays in critical interventions that could reduce ICP and prevent further neurological damage. For example, administering mannitol before obtaining a CT scan could be detrimental if the patient has a hemorrhagic stroke. Delaying neurological monitoring could result in missed changes in condition, and not implementing seizure precautions increases the risk of injury if a seizure occurs.
clinicalPearls: Rapid identification and management of increased ICP are crucial in stroke patients.
CT scan is essential to differentiate between ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke before administering certain medications.
Maintaining cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP) is vital in managing increased ICP.

questionTrap.trap: Many students might prioritize interventions that directly address the increased ICP (e.g., mannitol, head elevation) without first obtaining a CT scan to determine the cause of the increased ICP. They may also overlook seizure precautions due to focusing solely on ICP management.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Carefully assess the patient's presentation, review the provided data (especially the SBAR), and consider the potential consequences of each intervention. Remember that diagnostic information (CT scan) is crucial for guiding treatment, especially in stroke management.

mnemonic.title: I-ICP
mnemonic.expansion: I - Identify cause (CT scan), I - Intervene (Mannitol, elevate HOB), C - Continuous monitoring (Neuro checks, vitals), P - Prevent complications (Seizure precautions)
